autofocusEnabledInput.message: Autofocus the "$enableCheckboxLabel$" checkbox when popup opens

badgeWhatSettingToDisplayByDefault.message: What setting value to display by default

chartJumpPeriod.message: Jump period, %. Expressed as a fraction of chart length. Set to 0 for smooth movement (no jumps).

chartSpeedIntrinsicTime.message: Same as the current video speed

chartSpeedSoundedSpeedTime.message: Same as the current video speed, relative to sounded speed

contentScriptFail.message: Couldn't execute the content script on this page

couldGetMuted.message: it could get muted if we attach to it

disableHotkeysWhileInputFocused.message: Disable hotkeys while an input is in focus

doNothingWheneverPlaybackRateChanges.message: None of the above. Simply ignore playback rate changes from other scripts.

enableDesyncCorrection.message: Enable correction of audio-video desynchronization (side effect: for the most part unnoticeable stutter every minute or so)

extensionDescription.message: Watch videos ~1.5x faster by fast-forwarding long pauses between sentences

fileInputLabel.message:
Drop one or several files here
or click to select

hotkeysNotes.message:
Modifier keys (Ctrl, Shift, etc.) are supported.
Several actions can be bound to a single key. This can be utilized to create "profiles".
The difference between "$switch$" and "=" (a.k.a "set") actions is that "$switch$" toggles the value between the previous value and the hotkey's argument, while "set" always sets it to the argument's value.
Hotkeys are also active when the popup is open.

marginAfterTooltip.message:
This is similar to "margin before". When it was loud and then became silent, how many seconds we need to wait before speeding up (switching to silence speed).
This is mostly to keep pauses in the speech at least to some degree so words don't get mushed together and to ensure that you can clearly hear the very last letters in a sentence.
Unlike "margin before" this doesn't cause audio distortion & delay (but it's not to say that these settings are interchangeable).

marginBeforeTooltip.message:
When it's currently silent and then we encounter a loud part, how many seconds prior to it we need to slow down (switch to sounded speed).
This is mostly to ensure that you can clearly hear the very first letters when someone begins to speak.

âš ï¸ Note that non-zero values will cause audio DISTORTION when switching from silence to sounded speed AND will add constant audio DELAY equivalent to the value of this setting. These drawbacks do not apply if you use the "experimental algorithm".

noSuitableElement.message: Could not find a suitable media element on the page

omitMutedElements.message: Don't apply to muted media elements

preventOtherScriptsFromChangingPlaybackR.message: On some websites I visit, playback rate is getting changed in an unexpected manner. Don't let them change playback rate set by this extension.

rangeSlidersAttributesNote.message:
Be aware that browsers do not support playback rates above a certain limit.
At the time of writing it's 16 for Chromium (Chrome, Edge) and 8 (by default) for Gecko (Firefox).

refreshIfMuted.message: Refresh the page if the media got muted

runSnowflakeBridge.message: Help others circumvent censorship by simply installing (another) extension

silenceSpeedTooltip.message:
The speed at which we play the silent parts.
On the chart, the parts that were played at this speed have red ðŸŸ¥ background.$relativeNote$
âš ï¸ If this value is very high (> ~4) the beginnings of sentences may also start getting skipped (it's like "Margin before" is smaller).

silenceSpeedTooltipRelativeNote.message: Note that it is specified as a multiplier of the sounded speed, so e.g. if sounded speed is 1.5 and silence speed is 2, the resulting absolute value will be 3. You can change this behavior on the options page.

soundedSpeedTooltip.message:
The speed at which we play the video when it's currently NOT silent, the "normal" speed.
On the chart, the parts that were played at this speed have green ðŸŸ© background.

timeSavedAveragingMethodExponential.message: Only take into account the latest data (exponential decay)

timeSavedAveragingWindowLength.message: Only take into account the last N seconds of playback

timeSavedComparedToIntrinsic.message: on average how much faster the video is effectively playing compared to normal (intrinsic) speed

timeSavedComparedToIntrinsicAbs.message: time saved compared to just playing the video at normal (intrinsic) speed

timeSavedComparedToSounded.message: on average how much faster the video is effectively playing compared to sounded speed

timeSavedComparedToSoundedAbs.message: time saved compared to just playing the video at sounded speed

updateSoundedSpeedWheneverItChangesOnWeb.message: I want to control playback rate (sounded speed) through the website's UI or through other extensions, not just this one. This will update sounded speed whenever playback rate gets changed.

useExperimentalAlgorithmTooltip.message:
âž• ðŸ†• Now works on most websites!
âž• Allows skipping silent parts entirely instead of playing them at a faster rate.
âž• No audio distortion or delay.
âž– May break playback-related functionality on some websites.
âž– The chart won't display the actual volume on silent parts (it will just show 0 instead).

useSeparateMarginSettingsForDifferentAlg.message: Use separate silence skipping settings for different algorithms (related to the "$useExperimentalAlgorithmLabel$" setting)

volume.message:
Volume
It's not the current loudness of the material, but its amplification multiplier, like on TV

volumeThresholdTooltip.message:
When the current audio volume is below this value, speed up.
On the chart, this is the red ðŸŸ¥ horizontal line. The blue ðŸŸ¦ line is the current volume, so when the blue line is below the red, it is considered to be silence.

wheneverPlaybackRateChangesFromOtherScri.message: Whenever playback rate gets changed by other scripts

wouldHaveLastedIfSpeedWasIntrinsic.message: how long playback would take at normal (intrinsic) speed WITHOUT skipping silence

wouldHaveLastedIfSpeedWasSounded.message: how long playback would take at sounded speed WITHOUT skipping silence
